NSF has made an award in support of travel and registration fees for US students and post-docs to attend the AREADNE 2016 Research in Encoding and Decoding of Neural Ensembles conference to be held June 22-26, 2016, at the Nomikos Conference Centre, in Santorini, Greece. This will be the sixth conference in the biennial AREADNE series that provides opportunities for US students and scientists studying neural ensembles to be informed on the latest advances in the field, interact with their international peers and develop long-term professional relationships. The primary goals of the AREADNE conference include: 1)To provide an open, interactive forum to foster discussion of cutting-edge results from scientific leaders in the field of neural ensembles. 2) To enable the development of lasting professional relationships by creating an informal environment that predisposes attendees to free interaction. 3)To create a scientific venue that offers US investigators exposure to their European and Eastern Mediterranean peers in the field. Additionally, the conference will provide a forum to foster interactions of established investigators with students, post-docs and other young scientists in the field.

Encoding and decoding of neural ensembles is a developing field in neuroscience. The biennial AREADNE conference meets an important need in this field, as there is no other similar conference that provides a tight, focused, and intensive presentation of the subject and topics. Single-track morning and evening sessions with invited speakers and evening poster presentations will be used to disseminate the latest advances in the field and promote interactions among the attendees. Planned sessions include: 1) early visual systems, 2) decision making, 3) patterns and network synchronization, 4) connectomics, 5) learning and plasticity, 6) molecular mechanisms, and 7) visuo-motor integration. For each theme, presentations will emphasize how sensory, cognitive, and motor states are encoded in the interaction of multiple neurons and in turn how these states can be reconstructed from neuronal ensembles. After the meeting, proceedings will be published on the web for wide dissemination to the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
AREADNE 2016 Project Outcomes Report

 

Attendees

 

The AREADNE 2016 Conference was held 22-26 June 2016. There were 20 invited speakers, 6 contributed oral presentations, and 67 contributed poster presentations. There were 129 total participants from 12 different countries: 68 delegates were from North America and 61 from Europe and the Eastern Mediterranean.

 

 

Scientific Highlights

 

Presentations and discussions at AREADNE 2016 reflected the impressive quality and impact that the conference series has become known to attract. A selection of the talks from 2016 are summarized below as highlights of the meeting.

 

The first talk of the conference was by Edvard Moser from the Norwegian University of Science and Technology. He gave an elegant and clear overview of the functional properties of the medial entorhinal cortex including the well-known grid cells but also other cell types including head direction cells, border cells, and neurons that represent running speed. He then proceeded to discuss some of the mechanisms underlying the neural development of the grid-cell system.

 

Michael Roukes from California Institute of Technology discussed novel nanotechnology termed neurophotonics that will enable very large scale recordings of tens to hundreds of thousands of neurons with minimal tissue damage in the near future. His impressive probes enable electrical recording of large neural ensembles, but also chemical neuromodulation activity within specific cell types, and even the identification of synaptic strength.

 

Matthias Bethge from the University of Tuebingen discussed the potential of deep neural networks to perform complex tasks such as object recognition and semantic image segmentation. He demonstrated these computational structures generalizing their performance across different domains and reviewed some impressive results from image reconstruction.

 

Richard Born from Harvard University examined a long-standing fundamental question as to why cortical neurons exhibit such large trial-to-trial variability despite the presentation of identical stimuli. He demonstrated that cortical variability in visual areas could be reduced by silencing (via cooling) either bottom-up or top-down inputs to the these areas. He presented a simple model that reproduced these results when strong temporal correlations existed among the inputs that were silenced, suggesting that cortical variability may be due to fluctuations in synchronous inputs.

 

Finally, Michael Stryker from UCSF described experiments to reveal the neural circuits responsible for the enhanced neural responses of primary visual cortical (V1) due to locomotor behavior in the mouse. This high-gain state of V1 neurons has been shown to provide more accurate decoding of visual stimuli as compared to the resting state. Showing that recovery from sensory deprivation due to amblyopia occurs more quickly when visual stimulation occurs in the high-gain state, he suggested that locomotion not only modulates visual cortical activity but can also enhance plasticity which may have therapeutic implications for humans with visual defects such as amblyopia.

 

 

Goals and Achievements

 

The three goals for AREADNE 2016 were all met. The first, to provide a compelling forum for discussing cutting-edge results from the field of neural ensembles, was achieved as can be seen in the high-profile list of speakers and the sustained attendance throughout the four days.

 

The second, to enable the development of lasting professional relationships, was fulfilled by the daily schedule that allowed a large fraction of time for one-on-one interaction that supported the numerous, lengthy luncheon discussions, many exchanges during breaks, and the well-attended poster sessions that each lasted late into the night.

 

The third, to create a world-class scientific venue that offers US researchers exposure to their European and Eastern Mediterranean peers, is supported by the demographics presented above, the many personal comments the organizers received, and the overwhelmingly positive feedback form responses.

 

 

Broader Impact

 

The conference program book has been made available for free download as a PDF document from the AREADNE Conferences web site http://areadne.org. In the 12 months prior to 1 July 2016, some 2200 copies of program books were downloaded from all conference years combined. We expect the program book from 2016 to be similarly widely downloaded and carry broad impact.
